question: Question_08
statement:
Suppose that $\{ b_n \}$ is a sequence that satisfies

\begin{align*}|b_m-b_n| < \frac{1}{m+n} \quad\text{for all }m,n \in \mathbb{N}.\end{align*}

Prove that

\begin{align*}\lim_{n \to \infty} b_n\end{align*} exists.
sols:
We can show that the sequence ${b_n}$ is Cauchy. Let ε \textgreater{} 0,
then if \emph{n} and \emph{m} are larger than 1/(2ε) (that's the value
of \emph{N}, you can see from the argument below how we might have
guessed it), then if \emph{m} $\geq$ \emph{n}, we have that

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
| b_m - b_n | < \frac{1}{m+n} \leq \frac{1}{2n} < \epsilon\end{align*}

And since Cauchy sequences of real numbers are always convergent, we
know that the limit of this sequence exists.
hints:
Have you heard of
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cauchy_sequence}{Cauchy sequences}?
Try seeing if the sequence is Cauchy. If you haven't, first see if you
should (the curriculum might have changed since 2005).
